facts.text: Datar Singh convicted under Section 302 IPC by Sessions Judge of Patiala for murdering his father Thakar Singh at about 9.30 p.m. on 22-2-1970 at Naru House in Patiala, and sentenced to death.
Punjab High Court accepted death reference and dismissed appeal; also upheld convictions under Sections 25 and 27 of Arms Act for 2 years and 3 years RI.
Thakar Singh executed will in favour of wife and sons Avtar Singh and Datar Singh on 24-8-1967; cancelled it and executed another in favour of sister Rani Prem Kaur on 18-4-1968, registered at Dhuri.
Thakar Singh alienated property in favour of Jasvinder Singh, minor son of Joginder Singh PW1, about 1.5 years before murder; Avtar Singh filed pre-emption suit, pending at time of occurrence.
Strained relations between Thakar Singh and his wife/children; wife described him as sweepers son per Balbir Singh PW2.
Joginder Singh PW1 left Sunam at 2.45-3 p.m., reached Patiala by 4-5 p.m. on 22-2-1970; gave false explanation for absence on election day (baby ill).
Joginder Singh met Thakar Singh by chance at 8 p.m., invited to house; Balbir Singh joined after half hour; sat till 9-9.30 p.m. when Datar Singh allegedly entered with gun, shouted and shot twice.
Balbir Singh wrote letter Ex.X dated 20-4-1970 denying witnessing murder, police harassment; handwriting expert confirmed his writing.
FIR lodged at 9.55 p.m. on 22-2-1970 at PS Civil Lines Patiala; no time of dispatch to Magistrate; special report delivery to CJM claimed at 1 a.m. but unproven.
Inconsistent times: Joginder said appellant came at 8 p.m. in committing court, changed to 9-9.30 p.m. at trial; Balbir arrival 8 p.m. or 8.15 p.m.
No chick mentioned in FIR, seizure list, site plan; not seized; Peareylal DW8 said no chick, no body seen in room initially.
Medical evidence: Injuries from gun at 6 feet distance; no blackening; first injury left shoulder, second chest front right; inconsistent with entry and close shot.
Gun belonged to Mohan Singh (son-in-law); no fingerprints; ballistic expert could not connect cartridges to gun.
Appellant claimed at Delhi Sarai Gurdwara Sis Ganj on 22-2-1970; register entry serial 47 from 21-2 to 23-2-1970.
Appellant absconded, surrendered nearly a year later.

legal_issues.text: Whether prosecution failed to produce material witnesses, raising presumption against veracity.
Whether violation of Section 157 CrPC and its effect.
Whether violation of Section 162 CrPC by inserting witness statements in site plan and annexing to inquest reports.
Whether infringement of best evidence rule: no ballistic support, no fingerprints on gun, no chick seized.
Whether prosecution given benefit of doubt on alternative views; different standards for defence vs prosecution evidence.

petitioner_arguments.text: Eye-witnesses Joginder Singh PW1 and Balbir Singh PW2 unreliable: contradictions, false explanations, letter denying witnessing, inconsistent times, unnatural story of entry.
Prosecution defects: non-production witnesses, CrPC violations, best evidence rule infringement, FIR timing suspicious.
Motive weak; alibi evidence; absconding does not prove guilt.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Prakash Mahadeo Godse v. State of Maharashtra

respondent_arguments.text: Eye-witness testimony reliable; motive from strained relations and property disputes; appellant absconded, family influential but did not interfere initially.
Family won over witnesses like tall keeper, Harinder Singh.

court_reasoning.text: Prosecution case rests on brittle testimony of two eye-witnesses, inherently unreliable, artificial versions; suspicion no basis for conviction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Superstructure of prosecution case crumbles on examination.

court_reasoning.text: Joginder Singh PW1 entangled in lies about presence, false explanations; used 'do not remember' 25 times; no recall of conversation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Capable of false statements under pressure.

court_reasoning.text: Balbir Singh PW2 wrote letter denying witnessing; handwriting confirmed; prior conviction under S.409 IPC.
FIR timing suspicious, no dispatch entry; inconsistent witness times; no chick seized.
Medical evidence inconsistent with close-range entry shooting; distance 6 feet; no blackening.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Shooting likely from outside in dark.

court_reasoning.text: Gun not linked; no fingerprints; motive weak, others had stronger.

holdings.text: Suspicion, however grave, cannot be basis for convicting accused; prosecution must prove beyond reasonable doubt.
Eye-witness testimony unreliable; prosecution case fails.

precedents_cited.case_name: Prakash Mahadeo Godse v. State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Conduct like absconding does not conclude guilt.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Conviction under 302; prior conviction of witness under 409.

statutes_cited.name: Criminal Procedure Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Violations alleged; statements annexed to inquest to bypass 162.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court rejected applications; special leave granted.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allows appeals, sets aside convictions and death sentence under IPC 302 and Arms Act; acquits appellant giving benefit of doubt as prosecution case based on unreliable eye-witnesses crumbles.

key_quotes.text: Suspicion, however grave, cannot be a satisfactory basis for convicting an accused person.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Mere suspicion or suspicious circumstances cannot relieve the prosecution of its primary duty of proving its case against an accused person beyond reasonable doubt.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: If the pieces of evidence on which the prosecution closes to rest its case are so brittle that they crumble when subjected to close and critical examination so that the whole super-structure built on such insecure foundations collapses...
key_quotes.speaker: court
